name: Spiny Turtle
description: The marginal scutes on its flat shell protrude into spines, which are long and sharp in juveniles but less prominent in adults.
spread_note: Southeast Asia, including Indonesia and the Philippines
food_note: Invertebrates, fruits, tubers, and other plant parts, occasionally carrion and invertebrates
image_alt: Juvenile spiny turtle at Prague Zoo. Photo © Petr Velenský, Prague Zoo
reproduction: Females lay 1 egg (rarely up to three); incubation lasts 90–170 days, depending on temperature.
attractions: It inhabits streams in mountain forests and spends much time on land, foraging (even digging for food). It has short webbed feet.
projects_note: The species is listed in a category
breeding: Spiny turtles arrived at Prague Zoo in 2002 along with other species seized from the black market in Indonesia. The rescue of dehydrated, starving, and often injured turtles was organized by the European Association of Zoos and Aquaria. Prague Zoo took in some, preparing for the opening of the Indonesian Jungle pavilion. A major breeding success was that many species began reproducing, with three spiny turtle hatchlings emerging in 2012.
